title: In US v. California, will the District Court grant any preliminary injunctions against enforcement of California's “sanctuary laws"?
possible_answers: Yes, against two or more of the bills
preds: Perhaps I have some faith in the legal system.
Didn't even know about this q and everyone seems to be sure and WoC is 100% so do I even bother answering?  Won't gain much from it, but what the heck. Let's go all in too!
Well silly me I didn't realize the question is ending in two weeks. Guess I underestimated how slowly the gears of justice turn so I'm going all in on no.

Reasons previously cited.  Here's the docket list.  Prepare yourself.
https://dockets.justia.com/docket/california/caedce/2:2018cv00490/331791
AB 450 would require employers to refuse direction of federal employees. The requirement to forewarn of raids would need ICE cooperation. AB 103 likewise requires cooperation from ICE.

At first glance I thought my forecast would side with the states bills more than 50% in what is considered to be a liberal federal district court.  After actually looking at the content of the bills, there is, I believe a greater probability that the Trump DOJ may have a strong argument against these bills.  To justify a preliminary injunction however, is going to prove more difficult than winning the case in federal district court.
complex legal issues raise the chances of an injunction on any number of points
A long time Carter era appointee died yesterday I think and this make some difference to a full panel.
The district court will probably uphold the law and push it up to the supreme Court.  If they do strike the laws it will be all or none.
Precedent appears to be on the side of the DOJ.

The targeted California laws are Senate Bill 54, Assembly Bill 103 and Assembly Bill 450. It’s possible – maybe likely – the court would grant a partial injunction that doesn't knock down all three. Legal experts said each one will be reviewed separately, and the federal government faces varying odds on each.
Local law enforcement role in federal immigration Senate Bill 54 is the state's main sanctuary law that restricts how local law enforcement interacts with federal immigration authorities. It has the best chance of withstanding the court challenge, legal scholars said. “Here the state seems on the strongest ground, because the Congress has said the government can’t coerce states and local government,” said Chemerinsky Read more here: http://www.sacbee.com/news/politics-government/capitol-alert/article204188384.html#storylink=cpy
Premency of the US law over the state,  local governments are passing resolutions to obey the constitution over state law, California is becoming increasingly divided.

I'm breaking out of my comfort zone on this one to practice with a wider range of topics.   I'd really prefer to wait until we know judge(s) is going to be hearing this, but I think there is a strong enough case already to see an injunction against AB450 at the very least.

I guess I really don't know how the district courts will react to California's moves towards protecting its citizens regardless of immigration status. Will the courts really challenge the state? Or will it punt it to the Supreme Court? Here's the thing, I think the district court will punt. The problem is that if the Supreme Court takes it on, it will likely decide in favor of deportation due to court composition. That will have resounding consequences in the 2018 election, however.

California is operating like an entirely separate country already, and what passes for a legal system there is totally in the direction of supporting California's "laws." Even though we're considering the actions a federal district court may take, they still give higher status to California's laws than federal laws.

From one of the links: 
"Despite the passionate politics, the legal decision will rely on the merits of the arguments and past case law" Yeah, right. That last happened ... when?

It is extraordinarily difficult to make a legitimate case for either of these two bills, which are essentially wish lists.  Even the most wild-eyed liberal federal judges are not likely to let this go.

I think there is precedent from the opposite side when courts struck down Arizona's SB 12 for violating the supremacy clause. Amusingly, in that case is was because Arizona thought the Obama administration wasn't being tough enough. So to take each other these in turn. I think AB 450 will get an injunction as it compels or inhibits speech by employers. As well, legal workplace enforcement is a federal responsibility. I think SB 54 may actually be ok as it directs the activities and speech of state employees and that is within the rights of the state of California. Plus it has already been upheld in federal court. Lastly, AB 103 injects the California AG into a specific law enforcement decision and I think that singling out will be a cause of problems for the state's case.
The court will invoke the supremacy rule and declare that federal immigration laws have precedent over state statues.
Staying out of the Trump/Kim one for now. Some cloudy weather ahead on that one.
